articles.headline: Call to Congress: End Loophole for Tax on Elite
articles.snippet: Ending the policy that lets Wall Street’s top managers pay less tax on their compensation could be common ground for reform-minded Democrats and Republicans.
articles.abstract: Ending the policy that lets Wall Street’s top managers pay less tax on their compensation could be common ground for reform-minded Democrats and Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that Republicans control both houses of Congress, they need to show they can accomplish something, and President Obama has just two years to burnish his legacy. So the search is on for bipartisan consensus.

articles.headline: Europe Takes Aim at Deals Created to Escape Taxes
articles.snippet: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.
articles.abstract: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — American companies have plowed more money into the Netherlands than any other country in the world — for five years running.

articles.headline: The Big Money Behind the Push for an Immigration Overhaul
articles.snippet: Many of the gains made by advocates for immigrants to the United States were helped by hundreds of millions in donations from liberal foundations.
articles.abstract: Many of the gains made by advocates for immigrants to the United States were helped by hundreds of millions in donations from liberal foundations.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Obama announces major changes to the nation’s immigration enforcement system as early as next week, his decision will partly be a result of a yearslong campaign of pressure by immigrant rights groups, which have grown from a cluster of lobbying organizations into a national force.

articles.headline: Facebook Will Curtail Unpaid Ads by Brands
articles.snippet: The company said it was responding to feedback from its users, who were complaining about too many promotional posts.
articles.abstract: The company said it was responding to feedback from its users, who were complaining about too many promotional posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s executives are not terribly worried about upsetting people these days.

articles.headline: Vigilant Eye on Gender Pay Gap
articles.snippet: Employers who actively manage pay equity tend to have positive ripple effects, consultants said, including more women in their senior ranks.
articles.abstract: Employers who actively manage pay equity tend to have positive ripple effects, consultants said, including more women in their senior ranks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first step is admitting you have a problem, but it’s another thing to actually address it.

articles.headline: Some Retailers Promote Decision to Remain Closed on Thanksgiving
articles.snippet: Last year, more retailers decided to open on Thanksgiving, but this year others are promoting their decision to remain closed on the holiday.
articles.abstract: Last year, more retailers decided to open on Thanksgiving, but this year others are promoting their decision to remain closed on the holiday.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Thanksgiving, the open-versus-shut debate has grown even louder.

articles.headline: Tip on Medicare Spurs Insider Trading Investigation
articles.snippet: Federal regulators are looking into whether a report by Height Securities that led to stock price jumps among health insurers was based on information obtained illegally.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators are looking into whether a report by Height Securities that led to stock price jumps among health insurers was based on information obtained illegally.
articles.lead_paragraph: With only 20 minutes remaining in the trading day, a Washington-based broker-dealer, Height Securities, blasted out a “flash report” to nearly 200 clients, including some of the biggest hedge funds on Wall Street, predicting that Medicare was about to raise some reimbursement rates.

articles.headline: Hasbro Said to End Talks to Take Over DreamWorks Animation
articles.snippet: The end of talks between the two would be the second demise of a potential takeover of DreamWorks Animation since the fall.
articles.abstract: The end of talks between the two would be the second demise of a potential takeover of DreamWorks Animation since the fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hasbro has ended talks with DreamWorks Animation, people briefed on the matter said on Friday, ending discussions that would have united the parent companies of the Transformers and Shrek.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: City in Ukraine Tied to Masochism Finds Link Painful, Sure, but Some Like It
articles.snippet: Residents of the western Ukrainian city of Lviv are of two minds on the reputation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.
articles.abstract: Residents of the western Ukrainian city of Lviv are of two minds on the reputation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Taras Demlan was out for a quiet drink with friends in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a beguiling jewel of Hapsburg architectural splendor, and his companions persuaded him to try the specialty of the house.

articles.headline: One Drug or 2? Parents See Risk but Also Hope
articles.snippet: A steadily rising number of parents face a wrenching choice about whether to add antipsychotic drugs like Risperdal to stimulants like Adderall to treat children for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
articles.abstract: A steadily rising number of parents face a wrenching choice about whether to add antipsychotic drugs like Risperdal to stimulants like Adderall to treat children for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, Calif. — Every time Matthias is kicked out of a school or day camp for defying adults and clashing with other children, his mother, Joelle Kendle, inches closer to a decision she dreads. With each morning of arm-twisting and leg-flailing as she tries to get him dressed and out the door for first grade, the temptation intensifies.

articles.headline: Cost of Coverage Under Affordable Care Act to Increase in 2015
articles.snippet: Many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent.
articles.abstract: Many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday unveiled data showing that many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent — unless they switch plans.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear, Reed Abelson and Agustin Armendariz

articles.headline: Borrowers, Beware: The Robo-Signers Aren’t Finished Yet
articles.snippet: In Florida cases now pursued by debt collectors, some of the underlying foreclosures were based on dubious documents.
articles.abstract: In Florida cases now pursued by debt collectors, some of the underlying foreclosures were based on dubious documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember the robo-signers, those mortgage loan automatons who authenticated thousands of foreclosure documents over the years without verifying the information they were swearing to?

articles.headline: No. 1 With a Bullet: ‘Nadeshot’ Becomes a Call of Duty Star
articles.snippet: Three years ago, Matt Haag was flipping burgers at McDonald’s. Today he makes his living playing video games and has 1.5 million YouTube subscribers.
articles.abstract: Three years ago, Matt Haag was flipping burgers at McDonald’s. Today he makes his living playing video games and has 1.5 million YouTube subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Matt Haag, a professional video game player, makes close to a million dollars a year sitting in a soft chair smashing buttons. It is a fantastically sweet gig, and he will do about anything to keep it.

articles.headline: More Federal Agencies Are Using Undercover Operations
articles.snippet: Once largely the domain of the F.B.I., undercover work has increased across federal agencies as policies have changed, according to officials, former agents and documents.
articles.abstract: Once largely the domain of the F.B.I., undercover work has increased across federal agencies as policies have changed, according to officials, former agents and documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government has significantly expanded undercover operations in recent years, with officers from at least 40 agencies posing as business people, welfare recipients, political protesters and even doctors or ministers to ferret out wrongdoing, records and interviews show.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and William M. Arkin

articles.headline: New Senators Tilt G.O.P. Back Toward Insiders
articles.snippet: When Republicans take over the Senate in January, most of the members of the party’s freshman class will be people whose careers blossomed in the government bureaucracy that some politicians loathe.
articles.abstract: When Republicans take over the Senate in January, most of the members of the party’s freshman class will be people whose careers blossomed in the government bureaucracy that some politicians loathe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They have spent at least 70 collective years in government: five sitting members of Congress, two civil servants from the George W. Bush administration, a pair of state legislators and a former governor.

articles.headline: Cold Numbers on G.M. Crisis: A Peek Inside
articles.snippet: Kenneth Feinberg, a compensation expert, leads a team that determines who the victims are and how much money they should receive.
articles.abstract: Kenneth Feinberg, a compensation expert, leads a team that determines who the victims are and how much money they should receive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If this Monday is like almost every other one this fall, the death toll from General Motors’ defective ignition switch will rise.

articles.headline: Obama Calls Islamic State’s Killing of Peter Kassig ‘Pure Evil’
articles.snippet: President Obama called the execution of Mr. Kassig, a 26-year-old aid worker, “an act of pure evil” after it was revealed in a video on Sunday.
articles.abstract: President Obama called the execution of Mr. Kassig, a 26-year-old aid worker, “an act of pure evil” after it was revealed in a video on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Islamic State militants released a chilling videotape on Sunday showing they had beheaded a fifth Western hostage, an American aid worker the group had threatened to kill in retaliation for airstrikes carried out by the United States in Iraq and Syria.

articles.headline: Privacy Concerns for ClassDojo and Other Tracking Apps for Schoolchildren
articles.snippet: Many teachers say the ClassDojo app helps them record classroom conduct, but critics are wary of such apps’ ramifications for data privacy and fairness.
articles.abstract: Many teachers say the ClassDojo app helps them record classroom conduct, but critics are wary of such apps’ ramifications for data privacy and fairness.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTER, N.Y. — For better or for worse, the third graders in Greg Fletcher’s class at Hunter Elementary School always know where they stand.

articles.headline: John Oliver’s Complicated Fun Connects for HBO
articles.snippet: Mr. Oliver’s show, “Last Week Tonight,” is counterintuitive to the prevailing conventions of television, but has been a smash hit.
articles.abstract: Mr. Oliver’s show, “Last Week Tonight,” is counterintuitive to the prevailing conventions of television, but has been a smash hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, it’s nice to be wrong about something.

articles.headline: Defying Expectations, Japan’s Economy Falls Into Recession
articles.snippet: The country’s gross domestic product shrank by an annualized pace of 1.6 percent in the most recent quarter, threatening a planned tax increase.
articles.abstract: The country’s gross domestic product shrank by an annualized pace of 1.6 percent in the most recent quarter, threatening a planned tax increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s economy unexpectedly fell into recession in the third quarter, a painful slump that called into question efforts by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to pull the country out of nearly two decades of deflation.

articles.headline: Fear of Ebola Opens Wary Villages to Outsiders in Guinea
articles.snippet: In Guinea’s Forest Region, villages that have refused outside help to fight the Ebola outbreak are starting to soften their resistance.
articles.abstract: In Guinea’s Forest Region, villages that have refused outside help to fight the Ebola outbreak are starting to soften their resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANDANO, Guinea — “Bring out your sick!” the chief shouted angrily at the crowd, shaking his fist and warning of illness and death for the whole village if it did not obey.

articles.headline: Times Square’s Biggest and Most Expensive Digital Billboard Is Set to Shine
articles.snippet: The new screen is eight stories tall and nearly as long as a football field, spanning the entire block from 45th Street to 46th Street on Broadway.
articles.abstract: The new screen is eight stories tall and nearly as long as a football field, spanning the entire block from 45th Street to 46th Street on Broadway.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an era when digital screens large and small proliferate but attention is increasingly scarce, some marketers are making a huge bet that one of the biggest displays in the world will captivate audiences.

articles.headline: Iran Nuclear Pact Faces an Array of Opposing Forces
articles.snippet: As negotiations resume this week, there is skepticism among leaders in the United States and many of its allies that a deal can be struck.
articles.abstract: As negotiations resume this week, there is skepticism among leaders in the United States and many of its allies that a deal can be struck.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama wrote last month to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, urging him to overcome a decade of mistrust and negotiate a deal limiting Tehran’s nuclear ambitions, it was perhaps the president’s last effort to reach a reconciliation with Iran that could remake the Middle East.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Allergan Escapes Valeant’s Pursuit, Agreeing to Be Bought by Actavis
articles.snippet: The $66 billion acquisition by Actavis would be the largest deal this year and would thwart the takeover effort of Valeant and William A. Ackman.
articles.abstract: The $66 billion acquisition by Actavis would be the largest deal this year and would thwart the takeover effort of Valeant and William A. Ackman.
articles.lead_paragraph: After seven months of bids, bluster and lawsuits, the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals appear to be giving up their pursuit of Allergan, the maker of Botox, as another big drug maker has trumped their hostile bid.

articles.headline: Health Care Law Recasts Insurers as Obama Allies
articles.snippet: Antagonism over profits and regulation has given way to rising revenue for an industry, and legal and logistical support for the administration.
articles.abstract: Antagonism over profits and regulation has given way to rising revenue for an industry, and legal and logistical support for the administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Americans shop in the health insurance marketplace for a second year, President Obama is depending more than ever on the insurance companies that five years ago he accused of padding profits and canceling coverage for the sick.
